title: 112_hr6135
content: The Act titled "Transferring Credits for College Completion Act of 2012" requires data reporting. The Act "Transferring Credits for College Completion Act of 2012" mandates reporting completion data for degree-seeking undergraduate students who transfer from other institutions. This includes completion within normal time, 150%, and 200% of the normal completion time. The Act mandates reporting completion data for degree-seeking undergraduate students who transfer from other institutions, including completion within normal time and up to 200% of the normal completion time. This section will take effect one year after the date of enactment of the Act. SEC. 3. ARTICULATION AGREEMENTS. Transfer of Credit Policies under the Higher Education Act of 1965 have been amended to include requirements for institutions to indicate if courses are transferable for credit towards a degree at a public institution of higher education in the same state. The Higher Education Act of 1965 now requires public institutions of higher education to have articulation agreements with other institutions in the same state by July 1, 2014. These agreements must include a common general education core curriculum and common course numbering for transferable courses. The Higher Education Act of 1965 mandates articulation agreements between public institutions of higher education in the same state by July 1, 2014. These agreements must include a common general education core curriculum and course numbering for transferable courses. Tribal colleges and universities are exempt from this requirement. The Higher Education Act of 1965 mandates articulation agreements between public institutions of higher education in the same state by July 1, 2014, including common general education core curriculum and course numbering for transferable courses. The Act does not authorize the Secretary or the National Advisory Committee on Institutional Quality and Integrity to require specific policies, procedures, or practices by institutions of higher education regarding credit transfer, curriculum, program of instruction, administration, personnel, accrediting agencies, or associations. It also does not limit the General Education Provisions Act, require institutions to accept or enroll students, or create legally enforceable rights for students to demand acceptance. The Higher Education Act of 1965 requires articulation agreements between public institutions of higher education by July 1, 2014. These agreements include common general education core curriculum and course numbering for transferable courses. The Act does not allow the Secretary or the National Advisory Committee to mandate specific policies for institutions regarding credit transfer, curriculum, or enrollment of students.
